text.title: Avoid Dealer Status to Obtain Capital Gains
text.head: Avoid Dealer Status to Obtain Capital Gains
text.p: Two different groups purchase and sell capital assets : dealers and investors . Dealers are generally subject to more stringent financial and tax laws and regulations . If you are considered a dealer , you will not be able to claim capital gains on , for example , the sale of a property ; the sale will be considered business income . Capital assets include both securities and real estate . Of the two , real estate transactions are usually more complex .
text.head: Steps

list.item:
Decide what you want to do with the property you own . If you own a house , you may want to make improvements or sell the property .
Obtaining capital gains when you sell the property may be dependent upon whether you live in the house and how long you have owned the house . The process of " flipping " a house , or buying and selling it within a short period of time , may put you in the dealer category .
The method you use to sell a house could also affect dealer status . You might advertise the home as " For Sale By Owner " on a sign that you place on your front lawn to avoid being seen as a dealer . If you advertise in multiple newspapers and on television , you may be seen as a dealer .

Limit the number of properties you sell . If you own multiple properties and sell and buy properties frequently , the government may view you as a dealer . There is an extensive legal case history that determines the parameters for dealer status .
Subdividing a property for the purpose profit could propel you to dealer status . Frequency and the extent to which you develop a property to be divided also plays a role . In one case , a person with a non-real-estate job sold several lots of land over a twenty-year period and obtained capital gains .
Do n't set up an office from which you purchase and sell real property . Professional real estate agents have offices . If you open an office , the government may consider you a dealer .

Avoid hiring someone to sell your property , as in a person over which you have a supervisory role or a person who you have on a payroll . The government may consider this an activity consistent with being a real estate professional , which would put you in the dealer category .

Devote only a small portion of your time to purchasing and selling property to avoid dealer status . If you avoid devoting a significant amount of time to selling a property , the government may not consider you to be a dealer .

text.head: Tips

list.item: The factors that influence dealer status in real estate are evaluated on a case-by-case basis ; no single determinant is more important than another .

Avoiding dealer status may help lower your tax rate . In the United States , the 2011 tax rate for dealers who sell a property is 35 percent ; those who obtain capital gains are taxed at a rate of 15 percent .

text.head: Warnings

list.item: Investors should carefully review the rules that govern transactions involving capital assets to avoid dealer status and associated capital gains issues .
